searchDocs.title: Release 0.3.0
searchDocs.content: info Release 0.3.0 is out this week and the extension already have more than 100 users. SF Explorer 0.3.0 is back to school with a full internal rewrite now using jsforce and a couple of interesting new features: Security Explore your org security model with an interactive UI to make the bridge between theory and practice GraphQL Browse your org using GraphQL and generate LWC starters accordingly Usage Explore chosen records child relation at once

searchDocs.title: Release 2.0.0
searchDocs.content: info Release 2.0.0 is out this week and the extension already have more than 200 users. SF Explorer 2.0.0 is out with a full rewrite targeting an improved user experience: Right click in your page to open explorer or use the extension iconnon-intrusive: do not inject code unless you require it to do specific operations (like show LWC info): no more walking man in your page!taking advantage of the great chrome new side panelShow LWC info in your pageExport to excelAnd more...

searchDocs.title: But wait - what is Salesforce Explorer ?​
searchDocs.content: Salesforce Explorer is a productivity tool provided as a chrome extension intended for Salesforce administrators and developers. It contains features I needed on some of my previous assignments that I decided to package.

searchDocs.title: What is included ?​
searchDocs.content: Here is the list of the most important features provided:  Multi org Connect to multiple orgs to browse and compare records across them. Object Manager Retrieve key information on the objects you use the most. Explore Data Chain requests and Query data across multiple orgs with ease Explore Code Extract JSDoc information from your LWCs and your Apex to generate a status report Explore Omnistudio Get an overview of your omniscripts, DataRaptors and your flexcards Explore Products Explore Insurance Products with their coverage, attributes, rules and dependencies Interact with ChatGPT Get Contextualized help with ChatGPT to facilitate your work. Compare records Compare any other record in your orgs such as Flexipages, accounts or Flows.

searchDocs.title: But why?​
searchDocs.content: Most of the time I started working on something because I needed it on my project and I could not find the capability in salesforce or I was not comfortable with the user experience.

searchDocs.title: How is it built?​
searchDocs.content: It is built with React, Typescript and React SLDS to provide a salesforce like UX experience.

searchDocs.title: Why not an Appexchange?​
searchDocs.content: Web extension architecture offers the following advantages  First and foremost: No need to be admin of your org to install/use it!A single installation is enough for all your orgsReact, Typescript, webpack and friends offer a better developer experience than lwcInterestingly you can access the tooling API from a web extension and in LWC to do the same you need to a configuration with a connected app which is more complex in my opinion

searchDocs.title: Is it open source?​
searchDocs.content: Not yet, but the plan is to make it open source - code needs to be cleaned and documented first.

searchDocs.title: Can you use it on your project?​
searchDocs.content: Yes please try it out and let me know what you think. You can provide feedback here

searchDocs.title: Is it secure?​
searchDocs.content: Yes, like for the appexchange, chrome makes a security review for chrome extension and it has been approved

searchDocs.title: What and why​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer 3.0.0 is out with a focus on:  A brand new approach to be able to define best practices on your metadataNew capabilities to edit your data/metadata directly from SF Explorer

searchDocs.title: What and why​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer 4.0.0 is out with a focus on:  Improved performanceImproved UX and a new SOQL Query Editor (based on VSCode)A new feature: Data Dictionary Generation (from the object manager)

searchDocs.title: What and why​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer 5.0.0 is out with new features:  Schema Builder on SteroidsOpen API GeneratorRule engine testerWeb app deployment

searchDocs.title: UI integration​
searchDocs.content: Once defined, errors will be showned contextually on your records as you navigate through SF Explorer:

searchDocs.title: Setup Enhancement​
searchDocs.content: Enhance your Salesforce setup with checks and best practices with a new chrome extension called SF Explorer Advanced Setup  It adds custom message into your Salesforce setup screen to enforce your project rules are enforced. Your Design Authority should be pleased! You can add a custom messages for:  New Custom Object New Permission Set Those messages are configurable in the option page. It prevent user from creating duplicate fields It shows similar fields when opening a custom field

searchDocs.title: Command line integration​
searchDocs.content: It is simple to integrate those rules in your current pipelines, for example with a Github Action:    Create a file named .env with the following content:  SFEXP_LOGIN=XXX # remove it to use SFDX instead SFEXP_PASSWORD=XXX # Password+SecurityToken, remove it to use SFDX instead LOGINURL=https://login.salesforce.com #or https://test.salesforce.com DATE=TODAY #or 2024-01-01 RULES=EntityDefinition,CustomField #specify to only run rules on EntityDefinition and CustomField - remove param to check all rules   To connect with SFDX, don't use the SFEXP_LOGIN/SFEXP_PASSWORD env var.  Run the command:  npx @sf-explorer/devops.cli   The command will generate an output file name testReport.xml (in JUnit format).

searchDocs.title: Ignore metadata​
searchDocs.content: You can ignore specific errors with a file named .sfexplorerignore (using regex similar to a .gitignore file)  ignore an author with @ and the author nameignore a record with its type and target

searchDocs.title: EntityDefinition​
searchDocs.content: A custom object Name must be in english and PascalCase A custom object Description is required Less than 100 custom fields Maximum one custom trigger per object Maximum 15 record types per object

searchDocs.title: CustomField​
searchDocs.content: A CustomField API Name must be in english and PascalCase Custom Fields must have a Description (at least 20 chars)

searchDocs.title: Flow​
searchDocs.content: Flow Description is required (at least 20 chars) Flow Label must be Short Yet Meaningful

searchDocs.title: PermissionSet​
searchDocs.content: Name is following project convention Description is required (more than 20 chars)

searchDocs.title: ApexClass​
searchDocs.content: An Apex class name must be PascalCase and use a correct Suffix An ApexClass must follow the best practices An ApexClass must have a Description An ApexClass must have an author Apex variables must be camelCase Apex methods must be camelCase

searchDocs.title: LightningComponentResource​
searchDocs.content: An LWC must have an author An LWC must have a description

searchDocs.title: FieldPermissions​
searchDocs.content: No field level security on Profiles (except System Administrator)

searchDocs.title: OmniUiCard​
searchDocs.content: Flexcards names must be pascal case Flexcards must have a description

searchDocs.title: OmniProcess​
searchDocs.content: Omniscript Type should be camel case (for LWC compatibility) Omniscript SubType must be PascalCase Omniscripts must have a description Omniscript must have less than 100 elements

searchDocs.title: OmniProcessElement​
searchDocs.content: Remote action and DataRaptor Actions must have a description Set Values and Set Errors must start with Set+PascalCase Remote Action must start with 'Invoke+PascalCase' DataRaptor Extract must start with 'DRE+PascalCase' DataRaptor Post must start with 'DRP+PascalCase' DataRaptor Extract must start with 'IP+PascalCase'

searchDocs.title: OmniDataTransform​
searchDocs.content: DataRaptors must have a description

searchDocs.title: A CustomField API Name must be in english and PascalCase​
searchDocs.content: Field: DeveloperName Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9]*$  Example​  PhoneNumber

searchDocs.title: Custom Fields must have a Description (at least 20 chars)​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: A custom object Name must be in english and PascalCase​
searchDocs.content: Field: QualifiedApiName Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9]*(__c|__mdt|__ka|__kav)$  Example​  InsurancePolicy

searchDocs.title: A custom object Description is required​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$  Example​  More than 20 chars

searchDocs.title: Less than 100 custom fields​
searchDocs.content: Field: Fields.totalSize

searchDocs.title: Maximum one custom trigger per object​
searchDocs.content: Field: ApexTriggers.totalSize

searchDocs.title: Maximum 15 record types per object​
searchDocs.content: Field: RecordTypes.totalSize

searchDocs.title: No field level security on Profiles (except System Administrator)​
searchDocs.content: Field: Field  Example​  Use a permission set instead

searchDocs.title: DataRaptors must have a description​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: An Apex class name must be PascalCase and use a correct Suffix​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9_]*(Controller|CallIn|CallOut|Test|Helper|Mapping|Mock|TriggerHandler|TestDataFactory|Wrapper|Constant|Batchable|Queuable|Schedulable|EntityManager|ServiceManager|DataManager)$  Example​  ActivityTimeline_ControllerActivityTimeline_Controller_TestRetrieveInteractions_ServiceOutRetrieveInteractions_ServiceOut_MockRetrieveInteractions_ServiceOut_Test

searchDocs.title: An ApexClass must follow the best practices​
searchDocs.content: Field: Body  Example​  No DML in loopOptimize SOQL with related listsNo Hardcoded values

searchDocs.title: An ApexClass must have a Description​
searchDocs.content: Field: Body.description  Example​  /** * BoatDataService exposes utilities to manipulate data related to boat * @author "John Doe" * @date 25/04/2023 **/ public with sharing class BoatDataService { public static final String LENGTH_TYPE = 'Length'; @AuraEnabled(cacheable=true) public static List<Boat__c> getBoats(String boatTypeId) { } }

searchDocs.title: An ApexClass must have an author​
searchDocs.content: Field: Body.author  Example​  /** * BoatDataService exposes utilities to manipulate data related to boat * @author "John Doe" * @date 25/04/2023 **/ public with sharing class BoatDataService { public static final String LENGTH_TYPE = 'Length'; @AuraEnabled(cacheable=true) public static List<Boat__c> getBoats(String boatTypeId) { } }

searchDocs.title: Apex variables must be camelCase​
searchDocs.content: Field: SymbolTable.variables Regex: ^[a-z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Apex methods must be camelCase​
searchDocs.content: Field: SymbolTable.methods Regex: ^[a-z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Flow Description is required (at least 20 chars)​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: Flow Label must be Short Yet Meaningful​
searchDocs.content: Field: MasterLabel  Example​  Screen Flow:  Reschedule Order Delivery  Autolaunched Flow:  Users or Apps: Add Default Opportunity Team MembersFlow Trigger: Case Before HandlerScheduled: Remind Opportunity Owners

searchDocs.title: An LWC must have an author​
searchDocs.content: Field: Source.author  Example​  Here is an example  import { LightningElement, api } from 'lwc'; /** * Liste des contrats * @author "Nicolas Despres" * @see "Onglet Equipement" https://jira.atlassian.net/browse/XCC-71 * @param contract string */ export default class socle360EquipementDetailContrat extends LightningElement { @api contract }

searchDocs.title: An LWC must have a description​
searchDocs.content: Field: Source.description  Example​  Here is an example  import { LightningElement, api } from 'lwc'; /** * Liste des contrats * @author "Nicolas Despres" * @see "Onglet Equipement" https://jira.atlassian.net/browse/XCC-71 * @param contract string */ export default class socle360EquipementDetailContrat extends LightningElement { @api contract }

searchDocs.title: Omniscript Type should be camel case (for LWC compatibility)​
searchDocs.content: Field: Type Regex: ^[a-z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Omniscript SubType must be PascalCase​
searchDocs.content: Field: SubType Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Omniscripts must have a description​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description

searchDocs.title: Omniscript must have less than 100 elements​
searchDocs.content: Field: OmniProcessElements.totalSize

searchDocs.title: Name is following project convention​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name  Example​

searchDocs.title: For Object/Field pern sets,​
searchDocs.content: Start with the Object Name, and with the CRUD access provided, and anything special goes in the middle. Like this:  Account - (R/C/E)Case - (R)Case - Delete Access - No Fields - (R/C/E/D)Contact - General Access - (R/E)Contact - Sensitive Fields Only - (R)

searchDocs.title: For System Permissions​
searchDocs.content: Start each Perm Set with SYS so that their grouped together:  SYS - ReportsSYS - DashboardsSYS - View Setup

searchDocs.title: For App access​
searchDocs.content: Start with APP:  APP - Sales AppAPP - Service App

searchDocs.title: For Tabs:​
searchDocs.content: TAB - Accounts TabTAB - Tasks Tab

searchDocs.title: For Apex Class access:​
searchDocs.content: APEX - Account LWC ControllerAPEX - Case Invocable Actions

searchDocs.title: Description is required (more than 20 chars)​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: Remote action and DataRaptor Actions must have a description​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: Set Values and Set Errors must start with Set+PascalCase​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: Set[A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Remote Action must start with 'Invoke+PascalCase'​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: Invoke[A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: DataRaptor Extract must start with 'DRE+PascalCase'​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: DRE[A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: DataRaptor Post must start with 'DRP+PascalCase'​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: DRP[A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: DataRaptor Extract must start with 'IP+PascalCase'​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: IP[A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Flexcards names must be pascal case​
searchDocs.content: Field: Name Regex: ^[A-Z][A-Za-z0-9]*$

searchDocs.title: Flexcards must have a description​
searchDocs.content: Field: Description Regex: ^.{20,}$

searchDocs.title: How and Why?​
searchDocs.content: Here 25 min video explaining the behind the scene of SF Explorer

searchDocs.title: Problematic​
searchDocs.content: A number of frameworks and project implementations use Custom Metadata and textarea to stored structured information in json or XML. The approach is powerful but today the Salesforce Admin UI is not appropriate for this type of manipulation as it lacks:  Automatic indentationCollapsing sectionsSyntax validationSyntax coloration  Today you have to manual copy into third party tools and it is error prone.

searchDocs.title: Proposed solution​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer provides the missing edition capabilities with:  Ace Editor for syntax colorationStandard JSON parsing and validationDefault JSON formating with JSON.stringifySalesforce Metadata API to update the metadata in salesforce  Metadata can be retrieved and then edited from the query builder or the Metadata menu entry    Roadmap This feature is going to be enhanced with the folling tools: Prettier is going to be used in a future version for enhanced formating capabilitiesMonaco Editor is going to replace Ace Editor

searchDocs.title: Introduction​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer parses your Apex code to find JS Docs annotations, This information is then available in the UI.

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: /** * @author John Doe * @date 25/04/2023 * @description BoatDataService **/ public with sharing class BoatDataService { public static final String LENGTH_TYPE = 'Length'; public static final String PRICE_TYPE = 'Price'; public static final String TYPE_TYPE = 'Type'; @AuraEnabled(cacheable=true) public static List<Boat__c> getBoats(String boatTypeId) { // Without an explicit boatTypeId, the full list is desired String query = 'SELECT ' + 'Name, Description__c, Geolocation__Latitude__s, ' + 'Geolocation__Longitude__s, Picture__c, Contact__r.Name, ' + 'BoatType__c, BoatType__r.Name, Length__c, Price__c ' + 'FROM Boat__c'; if (String.isNotBlank(boatTypeId)) { query += ' WHERE BoatType__c = :boatTypeId'; } query += ' WITH SECURITY_ENFORCED '; return Database.query(query); } }

searchDocs.title: Compare Apex classes​
searchDocs.content: You can select 2 apex classes and compare them (works accross multiple orgs as well)

searchDocs.title: Introduction​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer parses your LWC contents to find JS Docs annotations, This information is then available in the UI. The content can be changed from this screen as well.    In the above example you can see in particular  description => Description column@see => we generate a link in the Link Column to serve as a reference@todo => will populate the Todo column  Various features like filtering and grouping are available, for example

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: import { LightningElement, api } from 'lwc'; /** * Liste des contrats * @see "Onglet Equipement" https://jira.atlassian.net/browse/XCC-71 * @todo "Redirection" */ export default class Socle360EquipementDetailContrat extends LightningElement { /** * Contrat * @type {import('c/socle360DataService').Contract} */ @api contract }

searchDocs.title: Compare Code​
searchDocs.content: You can select 2 LWCs and compare them (works accross multiple orgs as well)

searchDocs.title: Introduction​
searchDocs.content: The OpenAPI Specification (OAS) allows the description of a remote API accessible through HTTP or HTTP-like protocols. This description, which may be stored as one or more documents (such as local files or HTTP-accessible network resources), is called an OpenAPI Description (OAD)  SF Explorer Generate your org specific OpenAPI endpoints:  Generate specific object endpointsAdd custom apexAdd custom and standard actions exposed (invocables)Try out mode available => run against your orgDownload spec

searchDocs.title: RestApex​
searchDocs.content: Using the following Apex:  /** * APIs to retrieve or update clients */ @RestResource(urlMapping='/client/*') global with sharing class SFIDirectDatapackAPI { @HttpPost global static void UpdateClient(string payload, string dpStep, string status) { } @HttpGet global static void GetClient(){} }   Will result into the following spec:

searchDocs.title: Specific objects​
searchDocs.content: Supported features:  Accurate examples generated from your org dataRecord types supportedUpsert endpoints for all external idsExample provided with the composite API

searchDocs.title: Flexcard
searchDocs.content: Flexcard Flexcard explorer present how the flexcards are structured (parent>child>child...) When you are on a Flexcard, right click anywhere in the screen and select 'Open SF Explorer Panel'. From the Panel Menu, select 'Record Detail' option if it is not already selected. You should see the detail about children and parents cards: Note that the panel get refreshed when you navigate to another card.

searchDocs.title: Wait - what is Salesforce Explorer?​
searchDocs.content: Salesforce Explorer is a productivity tool provided as a web app or a chrome extension or intended for Salesforce administrators and developers.

searchDocs.title: Why did you build SF Explorer?​
searchDocs.content: Most of the features where built because I needed it on my projects. I usually work in design authorities so I need to understand quickly what is going on in multiple sandboxes. I am the first user and if it helps me, it may help others, so I decided to package it.

searchDocs.title: How is it built?​
searchDocs.content: It is built with React, Typescript and React SLDS to provide a salesforce like UX experience.

searchDocs.title: Is it open source?​
searchDocs.content: Some pieces are. You can find the different components here

searchDocs.title: Can I use in my own project?​
searchDocs.content: Yes please try it out and let me know what you think. You can provide feedback here

searchDocs.title: Who are the contributors​
searchDocs.content: Nicolas Despres and Florian Lebrun

searchDocs.title: Accesssing DataRaptor List​
searchDocs.content: The Dataraptors can be accessed from:  The Dataraptors menu under Industries entry pointThe Object Manager: this natively lets you explore the DataRaptors associated with a given object.You can also use the Search option and write your own query again the OmnidataTransform object

searchDocs.title: Finding where my Dataraptor is used​
searchDocs.content: To find the dependencies you can refer to the Used by column. It will brind all Omniscripts/Integration Procedures/flexcards that reference your DataRaptor.If you click on the number you will be able to navigate to the given dependency:

searchDocs.title: Finding what Dataraptor access/modify a given field​
searchDocs.content: From the Object Manager if you click on Calculate usage for all fields you will be able to find dataraptor dependencies at field level.

searchDocs.title: Comparing DataRaptors​
searchDocs.content: Select multiple Dataraptors and click on Compare Selected Items    You can leave comments on each row that will be saved in your browser.    info Any record can be compared this way

searchDocs.title: Testing DataRaptors​
searchDocs.content: You can test your Dataraptors from here as well (only on Extract for now)

searchDocs.title: Search Omniscripts/Integration Procedures​
searchDocs.content: Omniscripts and Integrations Procedures are grouped together as they are the same technical object. You can find them by using the Kind column.    info If you are still on a vlocity omnistudio org, you can change the namespace from here.    If you click on the Used By column you can find what FlexCard or other Omniscript use your given record.

searchDocs.title: 5 min introduction video​
searchDocs.content: Here is a quick recap:

searchDocs.title: Installation
searchDocs.content: Installation For SF Explorer to communicate with OpenAPI you need to: Sign up and generate an API Key (it takes 2 min)Go into settings (top left in SF Explorer) and copy paste your key into the openAPI key field

searchDocs.title: Configurable systems in 2023​
searchDocs.content: Nowadays systems are by design more and more configurable. Don’t get me wrong, this is great. However in many cases this also gives back a lot of responsibility to the end user. Over the years, developers have invented many tools to help them in their day to day work, such as:  Code autocompletionCode reviewsDeployment pipelineAutomatic testingLintingand much more,...  Wait a minute… What do we provide to our end user who is supposed to do something as heavy as configuring an insurance product? Not always much. This document is intended to explain how SF Explorer can help the product configurator in his day to day activity.

searchDocs.title: Why Product Explorer?​
searchDocs.content: The goal of Product Explorer is to help the Product Specialist in his configuration work that can be complex by providing:  An Helicopter View 360 degrees view of all layers, from product to attribute rule Dependency management Visualize dependencies between components Visualize recent changes at glanceBe alerted on configuration errors

searchDocs.title: Example​
searchDocs.content: The below example show a product class with 4 different product instances using many attributes. It is a particular good fit because many attributes are reused between coverages (which is often the case).  tip As a best practice try to name your attributes with a common name. For example, don't use Collision Limit but only Limit. We know it is a collision limit because it is in the collision coverage.  Here is what you should not do for example

searchDocs.title: Web version​
searchDocs.content: Visit https://app.sf-explorer.comClick on 'Add an org'

searchDocs.title: Web extensions​
searchDocs.content: Install chrome or edge extensionLog into your orgAnywhere in your page you can right click and select Open SF Explorer in the context menu or click on the extension icon'Voilà'

searchDocs.title: Term of use​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer is not a Salesforce official product. It can be used free of charge at your own risk. We recommand you to use it in sandbox environment with no production data. SF Explorer does not keep any of your data. searchDocs.title: Query Builder
searchDocs.content: Query Builder Browse your org data with the tool of your choice: SOQLSOSLGraphQLApex

searchDocs.title: Retrieve an SOQL Query and execute it​
searchDocs.content: Give me a soql query to search the last 5 modified accounts. Put your response inside a markdown code block with soql as the language   => The query will be executed

searchDocs.title: Retrieve an SOQL Query and execute it​
searchDocs.content: Give me a mermaid diagram in markdown showing an OAuth2 flow

searchDocs.title: Code Example​
searchDocs.content: Give me an example of apexrest api. Write your answer in markdown

searchDocs.title: 1️⃣ Grouping and filtering​
searchDocs.content: The proposed vizualisation is just an example - you can use excel like feature to regroup, sort or filter your data

searchDocs.title: 2️⃣ Object detail​
searchDocs.content: Your salesforce model can be complex like the InsurancePolicy FSC object below.    Interactive graph A node can be click to zoom on the associated object. A tooltip is also providing additional contextual information.  Note that the color of each node is associated to the selected profil/permission set group selected above (see 5️⃣ Object Permissions)

searchDocs.title: Introduction​
searchDocs.content: What is GraphQL:  Specification for API Server + Query Language - Facebook 2015Single endpoint for all the resources, that can be aggregatedRequests only the necessary dataSchema-driven, enabling introspection - metadata friendlyWidely adopted through a fast growing community  Useful resources:  GraphQL FoundationLandscapeSalesforce docsoql-to-graphqlFull stack TutorialSF Community groupannual survey results

searchDocs.title: Usage with SF Explorer​
searchDocs.content: GraphQL offers very interesting use cases for salesforce. A number of tools are available in the community and SF Explorer ships with a built in version of GraphiQL with the following advantages:  No need to authenticate - as easy as it should beSOQL transition toolSample queries to get you startedLWC Generation with the graphql wire adapter  To give it a try navigate to Code and then select GraphQL:

searchDocs.title: SOQL transition tool​
searchDocs.content: If you are not familiar with graphQL but you are a SOQL ninja 🥷🏿, you can use the SOQL transition tool:  Write your query with auto completion and the syntax you knowGenerate the graphQL equivalent

searchDocs.title: Playground​
searchDocs.content: Variables TLDR: Refer the variables with traditional SOQL Apex Binding ie :varname  Query  Loading...  info Beware that graphQL is case sensitive compared to SOQL

searchDocs.title: Provided examples​
searchDocs.content: If you open the history button you will find a number of queries to help you get started:  Search Accounts and their opportunitiesQueryAccountsWithCriteriaQueryCasesWithCriteriaObject info for Account and Case

searchDocs.title: 3️⃣ Nb records​
searchDocs.content: Clicking on the number of record of a given object gives you a quick access to the query builder for you to search or compare records of that given object

searchDocs.title: 4️⃣ Custom fields​
searchDocs.content: Custom fields columns gives you information on the level of customization your object contains

searchDocs.title: 5️⃣ Object Permissions​
searchDocs.content: To ease the transition to permission set groups, SF Explorer let you pick a profile and a list of permission set group to view/compare/analyze the impact on your model.    Once picked you can review the impact on each object with the Permissions column.

searchDocs.title: 6️⃣ Sharing model​
searchDocs.content: When the sharing model is Private or Public Read Only, SF Explorer provide a quick access the associated sharing table by clicking on the sharing rule

searchDocs.title: Compare records​
searchDocs.content: info The Diff column can be filtered to focus on the difference

searchDocs.title: Analyze records dependencies​
searchDocs.content: info SF Explorer analyze all child relation. It is possible to click on the number to view associated records.

searchDocs.title: Apex
searchDocs.content: Apex SF Explorer let's you run anonymous code in your org. You need to activate the DebugTrace to see the log and then you can retrieve the result with SOQL. /** @apex */ System.debug('Hello, World');

searchDocs.title: Apex
searchDocs.content: Apex SF Explorer let's you execute SOSL Query: /** @sosl */ FIND {"Franck" OR "Joe Smythe"} IN Name Fields RETURNING lead(name, phone), contact(name, phone)

searchDocs.title: Other features​
searchDocs.content: Some other important features:

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: SF Explorer allows you to browse your org model with SOQL queries with the following features:  ability to chain queriesautocompletionsortingpivotingability to run accross multiple orgscompare resultsquery analysis

searchDocs.title: Query Analysis​
searchDocs.content: /** @explain */ Select Name, Type, AnnualRevenue, BillingCity from Account limit 3   { "plans": [ { "cardinality": 1839, "fields": [], "leadingOperationType": "TableScan", "notes": [ { "description": "Not considering filter for optimization because unindexed", "fields": [ "IsDeleted" ], "tableEnumOrId": "Account" } ], "relativeCost": 2.8321557971014495, "sobjectCardinality": 1841, "sobjectType": "Account" } ], "sourceQuery": "Select Name, Type, AnnualRevenue, BillingCity from Account limit 3" }
